Award.AwardTitle: High Throughput Manufacturing of Carbide Nanowire-Carbon Microfiber Hybrid Structures and Polymer Composites from Cotton Textiles

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant provides funding for synthesizing large quantities of radially-aligned high-strength carbide nanowires using cotton textiles as both the template and carbon source. Nanowires are of great interest for use as reinforcements in polymer matrix composites but are not in widespread use today due to manufacturing challenges. The primary goal of this work is to solve the two most critical limitations in nanocomposite manufacturing, i.e., poor dispersion of the reinforcements and low throughput. The novelty of the approach is the controlled dispersion of the nanowires "by design" as the result of growing the nanowires on a substrate that is both the template and carbon source. This research program will study both the mechanisms of formation for the nanowires on the cotton substrate as well as study the reinforcing mechanisms of the carbide nanowire-carbon microfiber hybrid structures in composite structures. High throughput manufacturing of laminated polymer nanocomposites will be explored through specially designed spin casting and sheet molding processes.

If successful, the results of this research will contribute to a better understanding of the manufacturing-structure-property-function of carbide nanowire-carbon microfiber hybrid structures and their reinforced polymer nanocomposites. This research has the potential to change the conventional concepts for nano-reinforcement dispersion and to significantly impact existing nanomaterials manufacturing technologies. The research advances made through this project will generate new knowledge that will be introduced to undergraduate and graduate students through existing courses and the research activities will be used as an educational platform for students at all levels to learn about materials processing and manufacturing.

Institution.Name: University of Virginia Main Campus
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RECTOR & VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aims at synthesizing large quantities of radially-aligned high-strength carbide nanowires using cotton textiles as both the template and carbon source. Nanowires are of great interest for use as reinforcements in polymer matrix composites but are not in widespread use today due to manufacturing challenges. The primary goal of this work is to solve the two most critical limitations in nanocomposite manufacturing, i.e., poor dispersion of the reinforcements and low throughput. The novelty of the approach is the controlled dispersion of the nanowires "by design" as the result of growing the nanowires on a substrate that is both the template and carbon source. This research program has studied both the mechanisms of formation for the nanowires on the cotton substrate as well as the reinforcing mechanisms of the carbide nanowire-carbon microfiber hybrid structures in composite structures. High throughput manufacturing processes of high performance polymer nanocomposites have been established.

The results of this research have contributed to a better understanding of the manufacturing-structure-property-function of carbide nanowire-carbon microfiber hybrid structures and their reinforced polymer nanocomposites. The newly developed composites from this project exhibited a record high combination of elastic modulus, strength and toughness. This research has the potential to change the conventional concepts for nano-reinforcement dispersion and to significantly impact existing nanomaterials manufacturing technologies.

The project has enhanced the expertise of faculty in this area, helped recruit qualified students (2 female students), developed new educational opportunities, and increased the public awareness of NSF-driven research and educational activities in materials engineering and processing. Through this project, the principal investigator and students have established collaboration opportunities with 6 universities and 1 national laboratory.

This project supported 7 students (2 female students), resulted in 22 scientific papers in prestigious peer-reviewed journals, 15 invited talks and 6 presentations at international conferences/workshops, and 2 US patents (pending). The research activities were used as an educational platform for students at all levels to learn about materials engineering and processing. The research advances made through this project have generated new knowledge that has been introduced to undergraduate and graduate students through existing courses and newly developed courses (for instance, “Manufacturing Processes”, “Manufacturing and Process Technology”, “Micro/Nano Manufacturing”, “Nanomaterials”, and “Nano in a Global Context” offered/co-offered by the principal investigator). Students in these courses were given lab tours and opportunities to do their final course projects using facilities and techniques that were developed in the research. In addition, the research advances generated through this project were presented to high school students via lab tours in Discovery Day and the Center for Diversity in Engineering events. The research activities and findings have been covered by several media as news stories. 

 


Last Modified: 08/03/2015
Modified by: Xiaodong Li
